Verification of Williams' Test

Source: vignettes/articles/Verification-of-Williams-Test.Rmd
Verification-of-Williams-Test.Rmd
library(drcHelper)
#> Loading required package: drc
#> Loading required package: MASS
#> Loading required package: drcData
#> 
#> 'drc' has been loaded.
#> Please cite R and 'drc' if used for a publication,
#> for references type 'citation()' and 'citation('drc')'.
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'drc'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     gaussian, getInitial

Short answer: Yes for the PMCMRplus method. broom_williams doesn’t have a formal alternative argument, but it forwards any extra arguments via … to PMCMRplus::williamsTest, so you can pass alternative = “less” or alternative = “greater”. For the Williams_JG method, you should use direction = “decreasing” or direction = “increasing” instead of alternative.

How to verify with your dat_medium

  • Ensure the control is the first level of the dose factor (lowest dose first).
  • Call broom_williams with method = “Williams_PMCMRplus” and pass alternative via …
  • Observe the “comparison” column: for alternative = “greater” you’ll see “<= 0”; for alternative = “less” you’ll see “>= 0”.

Prepare the data: control first level 

dm <- dat_medium
dm$Dose_factor <- factor(dm$Dose, levels = sort(unique(dm$Dose)))
PMCMRplus with alternative = “less” (one-sided, smaller/decreasing) 
bw_less <- drcHelper::broom_williams(Response ~ Dose_factor,
                                     data = dm,
                                     method = "Williams_PMCMRplus",
                                     alternative = "less")
print(bw_less)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 6
#>   comparison     estimate `t'-stat` `t'-crit` decision method            
#>   <chr>             <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    <chr>             
#> 1 0.94 - 0  >= 0  -0.0664    -0.181      1.74 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 2 1.88 - 0  >= 0  -1.17      -3.20       1.81 reject   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 3 3.75 - 0  >= 0  -5.14     -14.0        1.83 reject   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 4 7.5 - 0  >= 0   -7.31     -19.9        1.84 reject   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 5 15 - 0  >= 0    -6.88     -18.8        1.85 reject   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 6 30 - 0  >= 0    -7.35     -20.1        1.85 reject   Williams_PMCMRplus
PMCMRplus with alternative = “greater” (one-sided, increasing) 
bw_greater <- drcHelper::broom_williams(Response ~ Dose_factor,
                                        data = dm,
                                        method = "Williams_PMCMRplus",
                                        alternative = "greater")
print(bw_greater)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 6
#>   comparison     estimate `t'-stat` `t'-crit` decision method            
#>   <chr>             <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    <chr>             
#> 1 0.94 - 0  <= 0  -0.0664    -0.181      1.74 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 2 1.88 - 0  <= 0  -1.17      -3.20       1.81 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 3 3.75 - 0  <= 0  -5.14     -14.0        1.83 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 4 7.5 - 0  <= 0   -7.31     -19.9        1.84 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 5 15 - 0  <= 0    -6.88     -18.8        1.85 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
#> 6 30 - 0  <= 0    -7.35     -20.1        1.85 accept   Williams_PMCMRplus
Williams_JG uses ‘direction’ instead of ‘alternative’ 
bw_dec <- drcHelper::broom_williams(Response ~ Dose_factor,
                                    data = dm,
                                    method = "Williams_JG",
                                    direction = "decreasing")
print(bw_dec)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 6
#>   comparison  estimate `t'-stat` `t'-crit` decision method              
#>   <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    <chr>               
#> 1 " - 0 >= 0"  -0.0666     0.181      1.74 accept   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 2 " - 0 >= 0"  -1.17       3.20       1.81 reject   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 3 " - 0 >= 0"  -5.14      14.0        1.83 reject   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 4 " - 0 >= 0"  -7.09      19.4        1.84 reject   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 5 " - 0 >= 0"  -7.09      19.4        1.85 reject   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 6 " - 0 >= 0"  -7.35      20.1        1.85 reject   Williams_StatCharrms

bw_inc <- drcHelper::broom_williams(Response ~ Dose_factor,
                                    data = dm,
                                    method = "Williams_JG",
                                    direction = "increasing")
print(bw_inc)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 6
#>   comparison  estimate `t'-stat` `t'-crit` decision method              
#>   <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    <chr>               
#> 1 " - 0 <= 0"    -4.00     -10.9      1.74 accept   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 2 " - 0 <= 0"    -4.00     -10.9      1.81 accept   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 3 " - 0 <= 0"    -4.00     -10.9      1.83 accept   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 4 " - 0 <= 0"    -4.00     -10.9      1.84 accept   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 5 " - 0 <= 0"    -4.00     -10.9      1.85 accept   Williams_StatCharrms
#> 6 " - 0 <= 0"    -4.00     -10.9      1.85 accept   Williams_StatCharrms

What to look for

  • In the PMCMRplus outputs, the comparison strings will end with “<= 0” when alternative = “greater” and “>= 0” when alternative = “less”. That reflects the one-sided hypothesis direction used inside PMCMRplus::williamsTest.
  • The JG outputs will reflect “>= 0” for direction = “decreasing” and “<= 0” for direction = “increasing”.

Notes

  • If you try alternative = “two.sided” with PMCMRplus, it may work (depending on PMCMRplus::williamsTest implementation) but Williams is commonly used as a one-sided trend test.
  • Always ensure the control group is the first factor level; Williams comparisons and Tcrit depend on the factor ordering.
